title: Pets Helped People Cope During Pandemic: Study
newstitle: "Pets Helped People Cope During Pandemic: Study"
content: wednesday sept. 30 2020 healthday news -- pets helped many people cope with mental stress of being locked down during coronavirus pandemic new study finds. it included 6.000 people in britain who were under lockdown between march 23 and june 1. about 90 had at least one pet. of those more than 90 said their pet helped them cope emotionally with lockdown and 96 said their pet helped keep them fit and active. findings from this study also demonstrated potential links bet.
abstract: more than 90 said their pet helped them cope emotionally with lockdown and 96 said their pet helped keep them fit and active ..
meta_keywords: "coronavirus, covid-19, pandemic, shutdown, pets, dogs, cats"

title: Statement on the fifth meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic
newstitle: "Statement on the fifth meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic"
content: fifth meeting of emergency committee convened by who director general under international health regulations ihr 2005 regarding coronavirus disease covid-19 took place on thursday 29 october 2020 from 12:30 to 16:05 geneva time cest. advice to who secretariat members and advisors of emergency committee were convened by videoconference.the director general welcomed committee highlighted global advances and challenges in addressing covid-19 pandemic.

title: As COVID-19 spread accelerates IHR Emergency Committee urges focus on measures that work
newstitle: "As COVID-19 spread accelerates, IHR Emergency Committee urges focus on measures that work"
content: emergency committee on covid-19 met on 29 october to review situation and progress made on temporary recommendations. they advised that pandemic still constituted public health emergency of international concern and urged focus on response efforts based on lessons learned and strong science. who director general dr tedros adhanom ghebreyesus accepted advice of committee stating that who will continue to work in partnership across world to drive science soluti.
abstract: emergency committee on covid-19 advised that pandemic still constituted public health emergency of international concern ..

title: UN welcomes nearly $1 billion in recent pledges - to bolster access to lifesaving tests
newstitle: "UN welcomes nearly $1 billion in recent pledges - to bolster access to lifesaving tests, treatments and vaccines to end COVID-19"
content: new commitments from governments international organizations and private sector support unified approach to end pandemic backing response of unprecedented scale scope and speedthrough access to covid-19 tools acceleratoras pandemic claims more than 1 million lives united kingdom 571 m us$ 732 m for covax pillar of access to covid-19 tools- act accelerator of which up to 500 m us$ 641 m is to support low- and middle income countries. this includes commitment to mat.
abstract: new commitments from governments international organizations and private sector support unified approach to end pandemic backing response of unprecedented scale scope and speedthrough access to covid-19 tools acceleratoras pandemic claims more than 1 million livesrecent commitments at glance united kingdom 571 m us$ 732 m for covax pillar of access to covid-19 tools- act accelerator of which up to 500 m us$ 641 m is to support low- and middle income countries. this includes commitment to match 1 for every us$ 4 committed by others up to 250 m us$ 321m).canada cad 440 m us$ 332 m for covax pillar of act accelerator of which cad 220 us$ 166 m is to support low middle income countriesgermany eur 100 m us$ 117 m for covax pillar of act accelerator all of which is to support low and middle income countriessweden us$ 10 m for covax pillar of act accelerator all of which is to support low and middle income countriesworld bank us$ 12 billion to support developing countries to purchase covid-19 vaccines as soon as they are available to be ratified by their shareholders)a coalition of 16 pharmaceutical companies and bill melinda gates foundation signed agreement to cooperate on vaccine manufacturing and to scale up productionthe united nations and its partners today welcomed monumental show of solidarity as governments private sector civil society and international organizations committed support to access to covid-19 tools- act accelerator initiative launched by world health organization alongside international partners.today nearly us$1 billion in new financing has been committed to initiative worlds most comprehensive multilateral end to end solution to devastating covid-19 pandemic.the act accelerator which wasco launched bythe world health organization european commission france and bill melinda gates foundationjust five months ago needs additional us$35 billion to realize its goals of producing 2 billion vaccine doses 245 million treatments and 500 million tests. new commitments to initiative are welcome and will be leveraged to catalyze further funding to continue act accelerators groundbreaking work.most urgently act accelerator requires us$15 billion to support immediate capacity buildingfor research and development manufacturing procurement and delivery systemsby end of year.convening high level event at 75th session of un general assembly to urgently mobilize support for act accelerator secretary general antnio guterres commended on extraordinary international effort to address human crisis like no other in our lifetimes adding that more efforts must be made to further deepen remarkable progress so far.it is in every countrys national and economic self interest to work together to massively expand access to tests and treatments and to support vaccine as global public gooda peoples vaccine available and affordable for everyone everywhere.the act acceleratorincluding its covax facilityis vehicle to get us there. investing in act accelerator will accelerate every countrys own recovery said mr. guterres who co hosted event with united kingdoms foreign secretary dominic raab south africas health minister zweli mkhize and director general of world health organization dr. tedros adhanom ghebreyesus.unprecedented global collaborationthe act accelerator which was launched just five months ago is unprecedented global collaboration of worlds top international health organizations working together to accelerate development production and equitable delivery of covid-19 tests treatments and vaccines.we have duty to ensure vaccines treatments and tests for covid-19 are available to allstopping global spread of pandemic protects british people and will put humanity on road to recovery. collaboration through act accelerator is critical to promoting development production and access for all countries said uk foreign secretary dominic raab.the united kingdom recently committed up to 571 m approximately us$ 732 m for covax. this includes up to 500 m for gavi advanced market commitment for covid-19 covax amc vaccinesa financing instrument that incentivises vaccine manufacturers to produce sufficient covid-19 vaccines to ensure access for developing countries.today uk foreign secretary called for more support pledging that this 500 m commitment would include 1 is$ 1.29 in matched funding for every us$4 committed by others for up to 250 m approximately us$ 321m).germany canada and sweden have also made new commitments to covax amc of euro 100 million cad$ 220 million and us$ 10 million respectively. these are eligible for matching with todays uk matching commitment.science is giving us solutions in form of new tests therapeutics andhopefullya vaccine. but science and solutions will be ineffective without solidarity said dr tedros adhanom ghebreyesus who director general.i am grateful for generous financial commitments made today but we still have significant funding gap to close. fully financing act accelerator will help to control pandemic restore confidence and stimulate global recovery. frankly this is not financial challenge its test of solidarity. this is moment for saying no to nationalism and yes to our shared humanity. because ultimately act accelerator is not delivering merely vaccines diagnostics and therapeutics. its delivering something far more importanthope.we must confront this health crisis as global challenge together in solidarity and cooperation with one another working toward global solution. we have to generate key tests treatments and vaccines that we all need and make sure they are distributed equitably to people who most need them regardless of where they live and whether their country is wealthy or not said south africas health ministerzweli mkhize adding that large parts of population especially in developing countries remain vulnerable and marginalized during this pandemic.todays event highlighted substantial results achieved by access to covid-19 tools accelerator initiative since its launch availability of 120 million affordable and high quality rapid tests for low- and middle income countries breakthrough in trials with and rapid rollout of dexamethasonethe only drug found to make significant difference to patient mortality creation of covax facility global mechanism to ensure equitable access to eventual covid-19 vaccines regardless of income -comprising 168 economies and largest and most diverse vaccine portfolio in world with nine candidate vaccines under evaluation eight of them in clinical trials.in another significant show of support coalition of 16 pharmaceutical companies and bill melinda gates foundation signed agreement to cooperate on vaccine manufacturing and to scale up production at unprecedented speed ensuring that approved vaccines are more broadly accessible and distributed as early as possible. bill gates co chair of bill melinda gates foundation said one thing i 've learned studying history of pandemics is that they create surprising dynamic when it comes to self interest and altruism. pandemics are rare cases where countrys instinct to help itself is tightly aligned with its instinct to help others. self interested thing and altruistic thingmaking sure poor nations have access to vaccinesare oneandthe same.a number of countries most recently united kingdom and canada are good models for what other wealthy nations should do. they have donated enough money for covax vaccine pillar of act accelerator to procure probably hundreds of millions of vaccine doses for poor countries. but more will be needed and i hope wealthy nations will continue to be generous.the world bank unveiled plans this week for significant financial commitment to support developing countries to purchase covid-19 vaccines as soon as they are available.world bank president david malpass said that once plans are ratified by stakeholders having up to us$ 12 billion available in finance will be game changer because once safe and effective vaccine is available it will allow people to resume their lives with confidence.investing in global recoverythe act accelerator investment case illustrates considerable economic benefits of collectively accelerating development and deployment of tools to rapidly reduce risk of severe covid-19 disease globally. prior to unga 2020 act accelerator has raised us$3 billion out of need of us$38 billion. more detail can be found in act accelerator investment case.the economic rationale for investing in approach that can accelerate end of covid-19 crisis remains clear.fully financing initiative to help shorten duration of crisis would pay back this investment in less than 36 hours once global mobility and trade alone are restored.notes to editorsthe access to covid-19 tools act accelerator is proven up and running global collaboration to accelerate development production and equitable access to covid-19 tests treatments and vaccines. it was set up in response to call from g20 leaders in march and launched by who european commission france and bill melinda gates foundation in april 2020.the act accelerator is not decision making body or new organization it works to speed up collaborative efforts among existing organizations to end pandemic. it is framework for collaboration that has been designed to bring key players around table with goal of ending pandemic as quickly as possible through accelerated development equitable allocation and scaled up delivery of tests treatments and vaccines thereby protecting health systems and restoring societies and economies in near term.it draws on experience of leading global health organizations which are tackling worlds toughest health challenges and who by working together are able to unlock new and more ambitious results against covid-19. its members share commitment to ensure all people have access to all tools needed to defeat covid-19 and to work with unprecedented levels of partnership to achieve it.the act accelerator comprises four pillars diagnostics therapeutics vaccines and health system strengthening.the diagnosticspillar co convened by global fund and find is focused on bringing to market 23 high quality rapid tests training 10 000 healthcare professionals across 50 countries and establishing testing for 500 million people in low and middle income countries by mid-2021.the therapeutics pillar is led by unitaid and wellcome trust. therapeutics can play role in all stages of covid-19 disease to prevent infection suppress symptoms and spread of infection to others treat or prevent symptoms as life saving treatment for severe symptoms and as treatment that can speed up recovery. aim in next 12 months is to develop manufacture and distribute 245 million treatments helping covid-19 sufferers to recover from disease.the vaccinespillar convened by cepi gavi and who is speeding up search for effective vaccine for all countries. at same time it is supporting building of manufacturing capabilities and buying supply ahead of time so that 2 billion doses can befairly distributed by end of 2021.the health systems connector pillar led by world bank and global fund is working to ensure that these tools can reach people who need them.cross cutting all of these is workstream on access allocation hosted by world health organization.for more information please visit who act accelerator website who.int/initiatives/act-acceleratorstatus report plan bit.ly/actacceleratorstatusreporteconomic investment case bit.ly/actacceleratorinvestmentcaseun covid-19 response portal un.org/en/coronavirusarchived video of event is available on un web tv.

title: Global partnership to make available 120 million affordable, quality COVID-19 rapid tests for low- and middle-income countries
newstitle: "Global partnership to make available 120 million affordable, quality COVID-19 rapid tests for low- and middle-income countries"
content: full access package includes who policy guidance on use of antigen based rapid diagnostic tests manufacturer volume guarantees for low and middle income countries catalytic funding to assist governments to deploy tests and initial us$50 million procurement fund several rapid point of care antigen tests are being assessed by who for emergency use listing eul agreements between bill melinda gates foundation and test manufacturers abbott and sd biosensor make availabl.
abstract: full access package includes who policy guidance on use of antigen based rapid diagnostic tests manufacturer volume guarantees for low and middle income countries catalytic funding to assist governments to deploy tests and initial us$50 million procurement fundseveral rapid point of care antigen tests are being assessed by who for emergency use listing eul)agreements between bill melinda gates foundation and test manufacturers abbott and sd biosensor make available innovative tests priced at maximum of us$5 for low- and middle income countries lmics)the global fund commits initial us$50 million to enable countries to purchase new tests with first orders expected to be placed this weekexpedited market introduction of these tests in multiple lmics is being supported through africa centres for disease control and prevention africa cdc unitaid find chai and their partnersthis is latest move from access to covid-19 tools act accelerator to develop procure and distribute critical new tools to fight pandemic new tests are urgently needed to meet huge unmet needs for testing worldwidea set of agreements to make available for low and middle income countries affordable high quality covid-19 antigen rapid tests were today announced by access to covid-19 tools act accelerator. organizations involved in milestone agreement include africa centres for disease control and prevention africa cdc bill melinda gates foundation clinton health access initiative chai foundation for innovative new diagnostics find global fund unitaid and world health organization who).as part of this comprehensive end to end effort bill melinda gates foundation has executed separate volume guarantee agreements with rapid diagnostic test rdt producers abbott and sd biosensor. these two arrangements will make available to lmics 120 million antigen rapid diagnostic tests ag rdts priced at maximum of us$5 per unit over period of six months. these tests provide results in 1530 minutes rather than hours or days and will enable expansion of testing particularly in countries that do not have extensive laboratory facilities or trained health workers to implement molecular polymerase chain reaction or pcr tests.the tests developed by abbott and sd biosensor are highly portable reliable and easy to administer making testing possible in near person decentralized healthcare settings. both companies tests are faster and cheaper than laboratory based tests enabling countries to increase pace of testing tracing and treating people for covid-19 at point of care particularly in areas with under resourced health systems. number of other ag rdts are at various stages of development and assessment.to scale up ag rdts global fund today announced that it has made available initial us$50 million from its covid-19 response mechanism to enable countries to purchase at least 10 million of new rapid tests for lmics at guaranteed price with first orders expected to be placed this week through global funds pooled procurement mechanism.find and who are working together to accelerate appropriate use by supporting implementation research that will optimize ag rdt use in multiple lmics in line with who guidance. this includes provision of catalytic volumes of tests to understand how ag rdts can best fit into health systems.unitaid and africa cdc will combine resources to initiate roll out of these tests in up to 20 countries in africa starting in october 2020. this multi million dollar intervention currently undergoing final sign off by their boards is designed to engage multiple partners active in covid-19 response in these countries such as chai african society for laboratory medicine aslm and local organizations. this will bolster efforts by african unions partnership to accelerate covid-19 testing pact initiative launched in august 2020 to mobilize experts community workers supplies and other resources to minimize impact of pandemic on african continent by testing tracing and treating covid-19 cases in timely manner.testing is critical cornerstone of covid-19 response enabling countries to trace and contain virus now and to prepare for roll out of vaccines once available. effective testing strategies rely on portfolio of test types that can be used in different settings and situations. while molecular tests started to be rolled out within month of virus being sequenced these tests are mainly laboratory based relying on infrastructure and trained personnel to conduct them. rapid tests to detect presence of virus at point of care which are faster and cheaper are vital addition to testing arsenal needed to contain and fight covid-19.who guidance published on 11 september 2020 highlights value of these tests in areas where community transmission is widespread and where nucleic acid amplification based diagnostic naat testing is either unavailable or where test results are significantly delayed. as well as supporting test trace isolate strategies tests can help identify or confirm new outbreaks support outbreak investigations through screening monitor disease trends and potentially test asymptomatic contacts.the act accelerator diagnostics pillar is co convened by find and global fund working closely with who and over 30 global health expert partners to accelerate innovation and overcome technical financial and political obstacles to achieving equitable access to effective and timely testing. such unprecedented global collaboration has enabled development and deployment of first who eul approved ag rdt within eight months of first identification of virus. in comparison it took nearly five years to develop first rdt for hiv. several more antigen rdts for covid-19 are currently under who eul review. overall act accelerator diagnostic pillar aims to facilitate supply of 500 million tests to lmics within 12 months.these agreements are critical to fulfil key objective of act accelerator to ensure all countries regardless of income have fair access to new tests and tools to fight covid-19. exceptional speed with which ag rdt access package has been created demonstrates breadth of impact of act accelerator initiative and this and future achievements in testing will complement similar milestones anticipated to emerge from vaccines and therapeutics pillars.dr tedros adhanom ghebreyesus director general of who said high quality rapid tests show us where virus is hiding which is key to quickly tracing and isolating contacts and breaking chains of transmission. tests are critical tool for governments as they look to reopen economies and ultimately save both lives and livelihoods.mark suzman chief executive officer of gates foundation said testing is essential tool in fight against covid-19. we are delighted to join partnership that will help ensure that latest high quality diagnostics do not just go to highest bidder but will be available at affordable price to worlds lower income countries. in addition all of actions announced today point to growing success of act accelerator in catalyzing global cooperation for fair and effective response to this global crisis.dr iain barton chief executive officer of chai said these agreements will help ensure that millions of people in low- and middle income countries have access to high quality rapid testing in villages and towns as well as cities. this has potential to revolutionize governments ability to respond to pandemic enabling quick diagnosis and response to contain localized virus outbreaks before they spread.andrea f. wainer executive vice president of abbotts rapid and molecular diagnostics businesses said abbott is pleased to bring our panbio covid-19 rapid antigen test and sympheos digital solution to people and health authorities in low- and middle income countries through this innovative partnership. we have long been committed to making sure our life changing technologies are affordable and accessible and for decades have been supporting many of these countries with our rapid tests for malaria hiv hepatitis and other deadly infectious diseases.hyo keun lee chief executive officer of sd biosensor said we sd biosensor are pleased to supply our standard q covid-19 rapid antigen tests for people who really need fast and accurate covid-19 diagnosis. through this partnership we will keep striving do our best to provide best quality of covid-19 antigen rapid kits for fighting covid-19.dr john nkengasong director of africa cdc said antigen tests are important complement to pcr testing and are crucial to expand testing capacity throughout africa. beauty of antigen testing is that it is fast and gives quick results. it will allow healthcare workers to quickly isolate cases and treat them while tracing their contacts to cut transmission chain.dr philippe duneton unitaids executive director a.i. said access to these point of care rapid tests with be game changer in fight against covid-19. we are working to support countries to rapidly deploy and use these new tests in best possible way. todays news shows what act partners working together can deliver in our efforts against covid-19 pandemic.dr carolyn gomes special advisor for board proactividad jamaica and alternate board member developing country ngos global fund ensuring equitable access to rapid diagnostic tests is essential for controlling covid-19 in all countries and to opening up economies across world. ensuring affordable price is major step forward. tests that can be used at point of care by front line workers will greatly facilitate community access to testing. to ensure equity in access for those who need it most there will need to be much greater support of act accelerator and diagnostics pillar in particular. much more money is needed to meet needs of most vulnerable. peter sands executive director of global fund said this is act accelerator in action. it is proof that by working together at massive global scale we can develop and deploy vital new tool to help contain and fight pandemic. this is not just new test its money and deployment plan to get it to where its needed fast. this is power of global collaboration.dr catharina boehme chief executive officer of find said with this ag rdt package act accelerator partners have secured much needed tools for lmics to dramatically increase covid-19 testing. with financial support of several countries we have made great progress but to ensure we reach all those who need testing and bring prices down we urgently need substantial funding from public philanthropic and multilateral sources.about act acceleratorthe access to covid-19 tools act accelerator is new ground breaking global collaboration to accelerate development production and equitable access to covid-19 tests treatments and vaccines. it was set up in response to call from g20 leaders in march 2020 and launched by who european commission france and bill melinda gates foundation in april 2020. act accelerator is not decision making body or new organization but works to speed up collaborative efforts among existing organizations to end pandemic. it is framework for collaboration that has been designed to bring key players around table with goal of ending pandemic as quickly as possible through accelerated development equitable allocation and scaled up delivery of tests treatments and vaccines thereby protecting health systems and restoring societies and economies in near term. it draws on experience of leading global health organizations which are tackling worlds toughest health challenges and who by working together are able to unlock new and more ambitious results against covid-19. its members share commitment to ensure all people have access to all tools needed to defeat covid-19 and to work with unprecedented levels of partnership to achieve it. act accelerator has four areas of work diagnostics therapeutics vaccines and health system connector. cross cutting all of these is workstream on access allocation. diagnostics pillar of act accelerator is focused on ensuring that everyone who needs test can get one. workstreams span research and development market readiness procurement and country preparedness. achievements to date include laboratory trainings in partnership with africa cdc in early february and suite of online courses deployed within weeks. nearly 20 million tests have been procured with diagnostics consortium ensuring diagnostic access for lmics and readiness for test and treat implementation in these countries. independent evaluations of antibody tests are also being conducted as high quality antibody tests are essential to understand population immunity for future vaccine roll out.for information about who s emergency use listinghttps://www.who.int/diagnostics_laboratory/eual/emergency/en/ https://www.who.int/diagnostics_laboratory/200922_eul_sars_cov2_product_list.pdf?ua=1.

title: Conflict, climate crisis and COVID-19 pose great threats to the health of women and children
newstitle: "Conflict, climate crisis and COVID-19 pose great threats to the health of women and children"
content: 25 september 2020 fragile gains made to advance women and childrens health are threatened by conflict climate crisis and covid-19 according to new report from every woman every child. protect progress rise refocus recover 2020 highlights that since every woman every child movement was launched 10 years ago spearheaded by united nations secretary general there has been remarkable progress in improving health of worlds women children and adolescents. for exa.
abstract: 25 september 2020 fragile gains made to advance women and childrens health are threatened by conflict climate crisis and covid-19 according to new report from every woman every child.protect progress rise refocus recover 2020 highlights that since every woman every child movement was launched 10 years ago spearheaded by united nations secretary general there has been remarkable progress in improving health of worlds women children and adolescents. for example under five deaths reached all time recorded low in 2019 and more than 1 billion children were vaccinated over past decade. coverage of immunization skilled birth attendant and access to safe drinking water reached over 80 per cent. maternal deaths declined by 35 per cent since 2000 with most significant declines occurring from 2010. estimated 25 million child marriages were also prevented over past decade.however conflict climate instability and covid-19 pandemic are putting health and well being of all children and adolescents at risk. covid-19 crisis in particular is exacerbating existing inequities with reported disruptions in essential health interventions disproportionately impacting most vulnerable women and children. at height of pandemic lockdowns schools were closed in 192 countries affecting 1.6 billion students. domestic violence and abuse of girls and women increased. poverty and hunger are also on rise.even before covid-19 pandemic child under age of five died every six seconds somewhere around world said henrietta fore unicef executive director. millions of children living in conflict zones and fragile settings face even greater hardship with onset of pandemic. we need to work collectively to meet immediate needs caused by pandemic while also strengthening health systems. only then can we protect and save lives.in 2019 5.2 million children under age of 5 and 1 million adolescents died of preventable causes. every 13 seconds newborn baby died. every hour 33 women did not survive childbirth and 33.000 girls day were forced into marriages usually to much older men. report examines deep rooted inequities which continue to deprive women children and adolescents of their rights noting birthplace as significant determinant of survival. in 2019 82 percent of under-5 deaths and 86 percent of maternal deaths were concentrated in sub saharan africa and south asia. nine in 10 paediatric hiv infections occurred in sub saharan africa. maternal newborn child and adolescent mortality rates were substantially higher in countries chronically affected by conflict.for too long health and rights of women children and adolescents have received insufficient attention and services have been inadequately resourced said former prime minister of new zealand and board chair of partnership for maternal newborn and child health helen clark. we call on all partners to work together to support governments to strengthen health systems and tackle inequities that constrain progress.the report calls upon global community to fight covid-19 while honoring and respecting commitments that can improve lives of women and children and not widen gap between promise and reality. covid-19 pandemic threatens to turn back clock on years of progress in reproductive maternal child and adolescent health. this is unacceptable said muhammad ali pate global director for health nutrition and population at world bank group and director global financing facility. gff partnership will double down on its efforts to engage with partners and countries and honor global commitment to ensure that all women adolescents and children can access quality affordable health care they need to survive and thrive.the past decade of progress to advance health of women children and adolescents must be protected from impact of pandemic and responses to it report says. rapid reversal of hard fought progress in womens childrens and adolescents health is real threat said ties boerma director of countdown to 2030 for reproductive maternal newborn child and adolescent health. as intensive tracking of covid-19 pandemic tells us timely local data are necessary to be able to target actions and prevent rising inequalities. global and country investments in local health information systems are much needed to guide response and protect progress. without intensified efforts to combat preventable child deaths 48 million children under age 5 could die between 2020 and 2030. almost half of these deaths will be newborns. report advocates for countries to continue investing in health of all women children and adolescents in all crises. "as we respond to covid-19 and reimagine better future with sustained peace including at home we must repeat unequivocally that rights of women and girls are not negotiable. even in times of crisis especially in times of crisis their sexual and reproductive health and rights must be safeguarded at all costs said natalia kanem unfpa executive director.the report argues that every woman every child movement is more critical than ever as we step into sdg decade of action in midst of worst global health crisis of generation. momentum of movement must continue to champion multilaterialism to mobilize action across all sectors to safeguard tremendous investments and gains realized by commitments since its launch 10 years ago and to protect health and well being of every woman child and adolescent everywhere. "there is no doubt that pandemic has set back global efforts to improve health and well being of women and children but that should only serve to strengthen our resolve said dr tedros adhanom ghebreyesus who director general. our joint action under every woman every child movement is more important than ever. we now must renew our commitment to healthier safer fairer and more sustainable world for women children and future generations.link to report microsite http://protect.everywomaneverychild.org link to who global strategy for womens children and adolescents health data portal https://www.who.int data maternal newborn child adolescent global strategy data.

title: UNGA Virtual high-level side event on mitigating the impact of COVID-19
newstitle: "UNGA Virtual high-level side event on mitigating the impact of COVID-19"
content: stewart simonson assistant director general wun moderated high level event hosted by co chairs of group of friends of solidarity for global health security on protraction of covid-19 crisis mitigating impact and protecting future generations. event looked at impact of protraction of covid-19 on future generations and importance of mitigating these impacts as well as what united nations member states and partners are doing to address crisis. welcomin.
abstract: event looked at impact of protraction of covid-19 on future generations and importance of mitigating these impacts as well as what united nations member states and partners are doing to address crisis ..

title: Managing the COVID-19 infodemic: Promoting healthy behaviours and mitigating the harm from misinformation and disinformation
newstitle: "Managing the COVID-19 infodemic: Promoting healthy behaviours and mitigating the harm from misinformation and disinformation"
content: coronavirus disease covid-19 is first pandemic in history in which technology and social media are being used on massive scale to keep people safe informed productive and connected. at same time technology we rely on to keep connected and informed is enabling and amplifying infodemic that continues to undermine global response and jeopardizes measures to control pandemic. infodemic is overabundance of information both online and offline. it includes deli.
abstract: coronavirus disease covid-19 is first pandemic in history in which technology and social media are being used on massive scale to keep people safe informed productive and connected.at same time technology we rely on to keep connected and informed is enabling and amplifying infodemic that continues to undermine global response and jeopardizes measures to control pandemic.an infodemic is overabundance of information both online and offline. it includes deliberate attempts to disseminate wrong information to undermine public health response and advance alternative agendas of groups or individuals. mis- and disinformation can be harmful to peoples physical and mental health increase stigmatization threaten precious health gains and lead to poor observance of public health measures thus reducing their effectiveness and endangering countries ability to stop pandemic.misinformation costs lives. without appropriate trust and correct information diagnostic tests go unused immunization campaigns or campaigns to promote effective vaccines will not meet their targets and virus will continue to thrive.furthermore disinformation is polarizing public debate on topics related to covid-19 amplifying hate speech heightening risk of conflict violence and human rights violations and threatening long terms prospects for advancing democracy human rights and social cohesion.in this context un secretary- general launched united nations communications response initiative to combat spread of mis- and disinformation in april 2020. un also issued guidance note on addressing and countering covid-19 related hate speech 11 may 2020).at world health assembly in may 2020 who member states passed resolution wha73.1 on covid-19 response. resolution recognizes that managing infodemic is critical part of controlling covid-19 pandemic it calls on member states to provide reliable covid-19 content take measures to counter mis- and disinformation and leverage digital technologies across response. resolution also calls on international organizations to address mis- and disinformation in digital sphere work to prevent harmful cyber activities undermining health response and support provision of science based data to public.the un system and civil society organizations are using their collective expertise and knowledge to respond to infodemic. at same time as pandemic continues to create uncertainty and anxiety there is urgent need for stronger action to manage infodemic and for coordinated approach among states multi lateral organizations civil society and all other actors who have clear role and responsibility in combatting mis- and disinformation.we call on member states to develop and implement action plans to manage infodemic by promoting timely dissemination of accurate information based on science and evidence to all communities and in particular high risk groups and preventing spread and combating mis- and disinformation while respecting freedom of expression.we urge member states to engage and listen to their communities as they develop their national action plans and to empower communities to develop solutions and resilience against mis- and disinformation.we further call on all other stakeholders including media and social media platforms through which mis- and disinformation are disseminated researchers and technologists who can design and build effective strategies and tools to respond to infodemic civil society leaders and influencers to collaborate with un system with member states and with each other and to further strengthen their actions to disseminate accurate information and prevent spread of mis- and disinformation.

title: COVID-19 pandemic: countries urged to take stronger action to stop spread of harmful information
newstitle: "COVID-19 pandemic: countries urged to take stronger action to stop spread of harmful information"
content: who un unicef unaids un development programme undp unesco international telecommunication union itu un global pulse initiative and international federation of red cross and red crescent societies ifrc together with governments of indonesia thailand and uruguay held webinar on margins of 75th un general assembly to draw attention to harm being done by spread of misinformation and disinformation latter being deliberate misinformatio.
abstract: world health organization who together with un specialised agencies and partners today called on countries to develop and implement action plans to promote timely dissemination of science based information and prevent spread of false information while respecting freedom of expression ..

title: The World Health Organization and Wikimedia Foundation expand access to trusted information about COVID-19 on Wikipedia
newstitle: "The World Health Organization and Wikimedia Foundation expand access to trusted information about COVID-19 on Wikipedia"
content: world health organization who and wikimedia foundation nonprofit that administers wikipedia announced today collaboration to expand publics access to latest and most reliable information about covid-19. collaboration will make trusted public health information available under creative commons attribution sharealike license at time when countries face continuing resurgences of covid-19 and social stability increasingly depends on publics shared under.
abstract: collaboration is part of shared commitment from both organizations to ensure everyone has access to critical public health information surrounding global coronavirus pandemic.

title: WHO SAGE Seasonal Influenza Vaccination Recommendations during the COVID-19 Pandemic
newstitle: "WHO SAGE Seasonal Influenza Vaccination Recommendations during the COVID-19 Pandemic"
content: this document from who strategic advisory group of experts sage on immunization provides interim recommendations for influenza vaccination prioritization of risk groups for seasonal influenza vaccination during covid-19 pandemic. it also provides programmatic considerations for national authorities planning and conducting their influenza vaccination programmes as well as research considerations to address current knowledge gaps. who sage seasonal influenza vaccination recommendations.
abstract: this document from who strategic advisory group of experts sage on immunization provides interim recommendations for influenza vaccination prioritization of risk groups for seasonal influenza vaccination during covid-19 pandemic. it also provides programmatic considerations for national authorities planning and conducting their influenza vaccination programmes as well as research considerations to address current knowledge gaps.who sage seasonal influenza vaccination recommendations during covid-19 who sage seasonal influenza vaccination recommendations during covid-19 pandemic.

title: Boost for global response to COVID-19 as economies worldwide formally sign up to COVAX facility
newstitle: "Boost for global response to COVID-19 as economies worldwide formally sign up to COVAX facility"
content: 64 higher income economies have now joined covax facility with further 38 economies expected to sign in coming days these self financing economies which include 29 from team europe participating as part of agreement with european commission join 92 lower income economies eligible for financial support through gavi covax advance market commitment this means total of 156 economies representing nearly two thirds of global population are now committed to or e.
abstract: 64 higher income economies have now joined covax facility with further 38 economies expected to sign in coming days.

title: Kim Sledge and the World We Want partner with WHO Foundation to re-record unity anthem “We Are Family” in response to COVID-19 and to focus on global public health needs
newstitle: "Kim Sledge and the World We Want partner with WHO Foundation to re-record unity anthem “We Are Family” in response to COVID-19 and to focus on global public health needs"
content: special edition cover of classic song we are family will be accompanied by worldwide viral video starring celebrities frontline health heroes leaders and members of public singing together in show of solidarity and support for addressing present and future global public health needs including covid-19. launching today wearefamily video campaign will invite people worldwide to star in music video recording videos of themselves with their close family and friends s.
abstract: special edition cover of classic song we are family will be accompanied by worldwide viral video starring celebrities frontline health heroes leaders and members of public singing together in show of solidarity and support for addressing present and future global public health needs including covid-19.launching today wearefamily video campaign will invite people worldwide to star in music video recording videos of themselves with their close family and friends singing song and then sharing this on their social media channels. part of proceeds from new song being released 9 nov will be donated to who foundation to support response to covid-19 and promotion and protection of health for people around world.a special edition cover of sister sledges timeless hit we are family will be released in new and inspiring call for global solidarity to respond to covid-19 pandemic and to generate proceeds to address most pressing global health challenges of our time. initiative is being launched by world we want global social impact enterprise and kim sledge part of legendary multi gold and platinum recording music group in benefit of who foundation and supported by world health organization who).this new initiative being launched ahead of united nations day on 24 october will also be accompanied by unique video and social media campaign and sound bold and hopeful call for solidarity unity and collaboration to promote and protect health and wellbeing for every person on planet.a call for solidaritythe inspiration to release special edition of classic track came in march 2020 as communities around world were left reeling from impact of covid-19.kim sledge said from doctors and nurses on front lines to paramedics and police from midwives and scientists to carers for vulnerable we are family initiative will salute each and every one with feeling of unity strength and solidarity in response to unprecedented challenges world faces as result of coronavirus outbreak.there are many people who motivated me to embark on this new initiative in support of making we are family come to life and who are very dedicated to finding ways to conquer this crisis. they include my close family friend lou weisbach my mercy seat ministry brothers and sisters and all of global health workers scientists essential labourers care givers and emergency personnel around world who have been working day and night during pandemic in support of others added kim vocalist philanthropist novelist songwriter producer and minister.using musics universal power in bringing world together wearefamily campaign is focused on raising awareness on and much needed resources for addressing global public health needs from emergency preparedness outbreak response and stronger health systems to promoting mental health and preventing non communicable diseases.natasha mudhar founder of world we want and driving force behind wearefamily campaign said we are family is one of most instantly recognizable anthems in world. song carries such inspiring message of unity and solidarity. we are certain that we are family song and video initiative is being launched at right time. it is rallying cry for togetherness for strength of our global family. we are all together during these times.special edition version song to support health effortsthe special edition of classicwe are familysong will bereleasedonlinefor download on 9 november 2020 in conjunction with theopening of world health assembly at whichkim sledgeis also scheduled toperformthe song alongside choral singers from new york to tonga. portion of songs proceeds will be donated to who foundation to support delivery of life saving health services.dr tedros adhanom ghebreyesus director general of world health organization said we are family is more than song. it is call to action for collaboration and kindness and reminder of strength of family and importance of coming together to help others in times of need.dr tedros added now more than ever communities and individuals all over world need to heed this message and come together as global family to support each other through this covid-19 challenge and to remember that our health and wellbeing is our most precious gift. i am grateful to kim sledge and world we want for sharing this masterpiece and message of hope with us all. it is only through national unity and global solidarity that we will overcome covid-19 and ensure people all over world attain highest level of health and well being. "join we are family video campaignin support of songs release call is being launched today 19 october for people worldwide to submit videos of themselves singing we are family for inclusion in unique and inspiring compilation video for release on 7 december 2020. this video will honour incredible work of frontline workforces risking their lives around to save ours and all those around world who have been affected by pandemic.to submit sing along videos to special edition cover version of we are family song key steps are record yourself singing we are family either alone or with friends and family whilst observing physical distancing guidelines.share video on your favourite social media channel with hashtag wearefamily covid19 healthforall and tag @who @the_worldwewant and @thewhof.upload your video to https://unitystrong.com.if you want your video to be considered for inclusion in global we are family video you will need to share your video by monday 30 november 2020.video clips will be selected based on age geographical diversity and appropriate physical distancing if video includes groups of people beyond immediate family members and correct handwashing if singing along to song while washing hands.more details including terms conditions can be found here www.unitystrong.com.for further information please contact world we want wafmedia@theworldwewant.global.

title: WHO SAGE values framework for the allocation and prioritization of COVID-19 vaccination
newstitle: "WHO SAGE values framework for the allocation and prioritization of COVID-19 vaccination"
content: this values framework offers guidance globally on allocation of covid-19 vaccines between countries and to offer guidance nationally on prioritization of groups for vaccination within countries while supply is limited. framework is intended to be helpful to policy makers and expert advisors at global regional and national level as they make allocation and prioritization decisions about covid-19 vaccines. who sage values framework for allocation and prioritization of covid-.
abstract: this values framework offers guidance globally on allocation of covid-19 vaccines between countries and to offer guidance nationally on prioritization of groups for vaccination within countries while supply is limited. framework is intended to be helpful to policy makers and expert advisors at global regional and national level as they make allocation and prioritization decisions about covid-19 vaccines.who sage values framework for allocation and prioritization of covid-19 vaccination.

title: Solidarity Therapeutics Trial produces conclusive evidence on the effectiveness of repurposed drugs for COVID-19 in record time
newstitle: "Solidarity Therapeutics Trial produces conclusive evidence on the effectiveness of repurposed drugs for COVID-19 in record time"
content: in just six months worlds largest randomized control trial on covid-19 therapeutics has generated conclusive evidence on effectiveness of repurposed drugs for treatment of covid-19. interim results from solidarity therapeutics trial coordinated by world health organization indicate that remdesivir hydroxychloroquine lopinavir ritonavir and interferon regimens appeared to have little or no effect on 28-day mortality or in hospital course of covid-19 among hospit.
abstract: study which spans more than 30 countries looked at effects of these treatments on overall mortality initiation of ventilation and duration of hospital stay in hospitalized patients. other uses of drugs for example in treatment of patients in community or for prevention would have to be examined using different trials.

title: Sixth Annual meeting of the “Friends of the Task Force” Working with Member States to deliver the NCD-related SDG targets during and beyond COVID-19

abstract: sixth annual meeting of friends of task force working with member states to deliver ncd related sdg targets during and beyond covid-19.

title: Impact of COVID-19 on people's livelihoods their health and our food systems
newstitle: "Impact of COVID-19 on people's livelihoods, their health and our food systems"
content: covid-19 pandemic has led to dramatic loss of human life worldwide and presents unprecedented challenge to public health food systems and world of work. economic and social disruption caused by pandemic is devastating tens of millions of people are at risk of falling into extreme poverty while number of undernourished people currently estimated at nearly 690 million could increase by up to 132 million by end of year. millions of enterprises face existent.

title: COVID-19 could reverse decades of progress toward eliminating preventable child deaths, agencies warn
newstitle: "COVID-19 could reverse decades of progress toward eliminating preventable child deaths, agencies warn"
content: with number of under five deaths at all time recorded low of 5.2 million in 2019 disruptions in child and maternal health services due to covid-19 pandemic are putting millions of additional lives at stake number of global under five deaths dropped to its lowest point on record in 2019 down to 5.2 million from 12.5 million in 1990 according to new mortality estimates released by unicef world health organization who population division of united nations depar.
abstract: with number of under five deaths at all time recorded low of 5.2 million in 2019 disruptions in child and maternal health services due to covid-19 pandemic are putting millions of additional lives at stake new york/ geneva 9 september 2020 number of global under five deaths dropped to its lowest point on record in 2019 down to 5.2 million from 12.5 million in 1990 according to new mortality estimates released by unicef world health organization who population division of united nations department of economic and social affairs and world bank group. since then however surveys by unicef and who reveal that covid-19 pandemic has resulted in major disruptions to health services that threaten to undo decades of hard won progress. global community has come too far towards eliminating preventable child deaths to allow covid-19 pandemic to stop us in our tracks said henrietta fore unicef executive director. when children are denied access to health services because system is overrun and when women are afraid to give birth at hospital for fear of infection they too may become casualties of covid-19. without urgent investments to re start disrupted health systems and services millions of children under five especially newborns could die. over past 30 years health services to prevent or treat causes of child death such as preterm low birthweight complications during birth neonatal sepsis pneumonia diarrhea and malaria as well as vaccination have played large role in saving millions of lives. now countries worldwide are experiencing disruptions in child and maternal health services such as health checkups vaccinations and prenatal and post natal care due to resource constraints and general uneasiness with using health services due to fear of getting covid-19. unicef survey conducted over summer across 77 countries found that almost 68 per cent of countries reported at least some disruption in health checks for children and immunization services. in addition 63 per cent of countries reported disruptions in antenatal checkups and 59 per cent in post natal care. recent who survey based on responses from 105 countries revealed that 52 per cent of countries reported disruptions in health services for sick children and 51 per cent in services for management of malnutrition. health interventions such as these are critical for stopping preventable newborn and child deaths. for example women who receive care by professional midwives trained according to internationals standards are 16 per cent less likely to lose their baby and 24 per cent less likely to experience pre term birth according to who. fact that today more children live to see their first birthday than any time in history is true mark of what can be achieved when world puts health and well being at centre of our response said dr. tedros adhanom ghebreyesus who director general. now we must not let covid-19 pandemic turn back remarkable progress for our children and future generations. rather its time to use what we know works to save lives and keep investing in stronger resilient health systems. based on responses from countries that participated in unicef and who surveys most commonly cited reasons for health service disruptions included parents avoiding health centers for fear of infection transport restrictions suspension or closure of services and facilities fewer healthcare workers due to diversions or fear of infection due to shortages in personal protective equipment such as masks and gloves and greater financial difficulties. afghanistan bolivia cameroon central african republic libya madagascar pakistan sudan and yemen are among hardest hit countries. seven of nine countries had high child mortality rates of more than 50 deaths per 1000 live births among children under five in 2019. in afghanistan where 1 in 17 children died before reaching age 5 in 2019 ministry of health reported significant reduction in visits to health facilities. out of fear of contracting covid-19 virus families are de prioritizing pre- and post natal care adding to risk faced by pregnant women and newborn babies. even before covid-19 newborns were at highest risk of death. in 2019 newborn baby died every 13 seconds. moreover 47 per cent of all under five deaths occurred in neonatal period up from 40 per cent in 1990. with severe disruptions in essential health services newborn babies could be at much higher risk of dying. for example in cameroon where 1 out of every 38 newborns died in 2019 unicef survey reported estimated 75 per cent disruptions in services for essential newborn care antenatal check ups obstetric care and post natal care. in may initial modelling by johns hopkins university showed that almost 6.000 additional children could die per day due to disruptions due to covid-19. these reports and surveys highlight need for urgent action to restore and improve childbirth services and antenatal and postnatal care for mothers and babies including having skilled health workers to care for them at birth. working with parents to assuage their fears and reassure them is also important. covid-19 pandemic has put years of global progress to end preventable child deaths in serious jeopardy said muhammad ali pate global director for health nutrition and population at world bank. it is essential to protect life saving services which have been key to reducing child mortality. we will continue to work with governments and partners to reinforce healthcare systems to ensure mothers and children get services they need. new report demonstrates ongoing progress worldwide in reducing child mortality said john wilmoth director of population division of united nations department of economic and social affairs. while report highlights negative effects of covid-19 pandemic on interventions that are critical for childrens health it also draws attention to need to redress vast inequities in child 's prospects for survival and good health. download photos b roll full child mortality estimates report and data files here. for unicef survey on disruptions due to covid-19 click here. these links will go live after 00.01 gmt 9 september. main report landing page https://data.unicef.org/resources/levels-and-trends-in-child-mortality/datasets https://data.unicef.org/resources/dataset/child-mortality/ narrative page https://data.unicef.org/topic/child-survival/under-five-mortality/ about un igme united nations inter agency group for child mortality estimation or un igme was formed in 2004 to share data on child mortality improve methods for child mortality estimation report on progress towards child survival goals and enhance country capacity to produce timely and properly assessed estimates of child mortality. un igme is led by unicef and includes world health organization world bank group and united nations population division of department of economic and social affairs. for more information visit http://www.childmortality.org/ for more information please contact sabrina sidhu unicef new york +1 917 4761537 ssidhu@unicef.org fadla chaib who geneva +41 79 475 5556 chaibf@who.int bela hovy population division un desa 1 914 602 3370 hovy@un.orgalexandra humme world bank washington dc +12024585511 ahumme@worldbank.org.

title: Malaria and COVID-19: country perspectives
newstitle: "Malaria and COVID-19: country perspectives"
content: how have country based malaria experts adapted to double challenge of malaria and covid-19. what successes have they achieved and where are remaining gaps. in virtual forum on 3 september 10 ministry of health representatives shared their experiences and reflections you can watch their presentations below. on 4 september participants heard from senior political and health leaders from 2 regions that are heavily impacted by malaria you will find below presentations of who s re.
abstract: two virtual forums on 3 4 september co hosted by who and rbm partnership to end malaria took stock of current situation in countries affected by both malaria and covid-19 including successes pain points best practices and lessons learned. on day 1 participants heard from country based experts about incredible work that has been done to maintain critical malaria services. their shared insights formed basis of discussions on day 2 with national and global health leaders.

title: COVID-19 disrupting mental health services in most countries
newstitle: "COVID-19 disrupting mental health services in most countries, WHO survey"
content: covid-19 pandemic has disrupted or halted critical mental health services in 93 of countries worldwide while demand for mental health is increasing according to new who survey. survey of 130 countries provides first global data showing devastating impact of covid-19 on access to mental health services and underscores urgent need for increased funding. survey was published ahead of who s big event for mental health global online advocacy event on 10 october.
abstract: covid-19 pandemic has disrupted or halted critical mental health services in 93 of countries worldwide while demand for mental health is increasing according to new who survey. survey of 130 countries provides first global data showing devastating impact of covid-19 on access to mental health services and underscores urgent need for increased funding.the survey was published ahead of who s big event for mental health global online advocacy event on 10 october that will bring together world leaders celebrities and advocates to call for increased mental health investments in wake of covid-19.who has previously highlighted chronic underfunding of mental health prior to pandemic countries were spending less than 2 per cent of their national health budgets on mental health and struggling to meet their populations needs.and pandemic is increasing demand for mental health services. bereavement isolation loss of income and fear are triggering mental health conditions or exacerbating existing ones. many people may be facing increased levels of alcohol and drug use insomnia and anxiety. meanwhile covid-19 itself can lead to neurological and mental complications such as delirium agitation and stroke. people with pre existing mental neurological or substance use disorders are also more vulnerable to sars cov-2 infection they may stand higher risk of severe outcomes and even death.good mental health is absolutely fundamental to overall health and well being said dr tedros adhanom ghebreyesus director general of world health organization. covid-19 has interrupted essential mental health services around world just when they re needed most. world leaders must move fast and decisively to invest more in life saving mental health programmes during pandemic and beyond. survey finds major disruptions to critical mental health services survey was conducted from june to august 2020 among 130 countries across who s six regions. it evaluates how provision of mental neurological and substance use services has changed due to covid-19 types of services that have been disrupted and how countries are adapting to overcome these challenges.countries reported widespread disruption of many kinds of critical mental health services over 60 reported disruptions to mental health services for vulnerable people including children and adolescents 72 older adults 70 and women requiring antenatal or postnatal services 61%).67 saw disruptions to counseling and psychotherapy 65 to critical harm reduction services and 45 to opioid agonist maintenance treatment for opioid dependence.more than third 35 reported disruptions to emergency interventions including those for people experiencing prolonged seizures severe substance use withdrawal syndromes and delirium often sign of serious underlying medical condition.30 reported disruptions to access for medications for mental neurological and substance use disorders.around three quarters reported at least partial disruptions to school and workplace mental health services 78 and 75 respectively).while many countries 70 have adopted telemedicine or teletherapy to overcome disruptions to in person services there are significant disparities in uptake of these interventions. more than 80 of high income countries reported deploying telemedicine and teletherapy to bridge gaps in mental health compared with less than 50 of low income countries.who has issued guidance to countries on how to maintain essential services including mental health services during covid-19 and recommends that countries allocate resources to mental health as integral component of their response and recovery plans. organization also urges countries to monitor changes and disruptions in services so that they can address them as required.although 89 of countries reported in survey that mental health and psychosocial support is part of their national covid-19 response plans only 17 of these countries have full additional funding for covering these activities.this all highlights need for more money for mental health. as pandemic continues even greater demand will be placed on national and international mental health programmes that have suffered from years of chronic underfunding. spending 2 of national health budgets on mental health is not enough. international funders also need to do more mental health still receives less than 1 of international aid earmarked for health.those who do invest in mental health will reap rewards. pre covid-19 estimates reveal that nearly us$ 1 trillion in economic productivity is lost annually from depression and anxiety alone. however studies show that every us$ 1 spent on evidence based care for depression and anxiety returns us$5.note on world mental health day mobilizing global community to moveformentalheatlh on world mental health day saturday 10 october as part of its campaign move for mental health lets invest who is inviting global community to take part in big event for mental health unprecedented online advocacy event that will call for increased investment in mental health at all levels from individuals to businesses to countries to civil society so that world can begin to close gaps highlighted by todays report. big event is free and open to public and will be broadcast on 10 october from 16:00 to 19:00 cest on who s youtube facebook twitter tiktok and linkedin channels and website. for updated information about big event for mental health including latest lineup of performances and participants visit big event web page. to learn more about world mental health day visit who s campaign page.

title: COVID-19 Science Update released: October 30
newstitle: "CDC Library: COVID-19 Science Update: 10/30/2020"
content: cytokine storm syndrome seen in some covid-19 patients results from excessive inflammatory response that can aggravate respiratory failure and lead to systemic organ failure and death. cytokine interleukin-6 il-6 has appears to be potentially important mediator of cytokine storm syndrome. tocilizumab monoclonal antibody that blocks il-6 and is used to treat rheumatoid arthritis has been examined as potential treatment for covid-19. below we share summaries of series of s.
abstract: covid-19 science update produced by office of chief science officer covid-19 in conjunction with stephen b. thacker cdc library.
meta_keywords: "High serum IL-6 values increase the risk of mortality and the severity of pneumonia in patients diagnosed with COVID-19. Guirao et al. Molecular Immunology, • IL-6 serum concentrations above 35 pg/mL were associated with a higher risk of (Figure): o More severe pneumonia (OR = 4.47, 95% CI 1.15-17.45, p = 0.031). o Increased risk of mortality (OR = 20.00, 95% CI 4.21-94.91, p = 0.0001). o ICU admission (OR = 12.75, 95% CI 2.16-75.33, p = 0.005). • Of the 27 patients treated with tocilizumab, 8 (28%) died, while 6 (26%) of the 23 patients who were not treated with tocilizumab died., Effect of tocilizumab vs usual care in adults hospitalized with COVID-19 and moderate or severe pneumonia: A randomized clinical trial. Hermine et al. JAMA Internal Medicine, • Patients receiving tocilizumab had similar scores to the usual care [UC] group on the World Health Organization 10-point Clinical Progression Scale (WHO-CPS) on day 4 (Figure). o 12 of 63 (19%) patients randomized to receive tocilizumab had a WHO-CPS score higher than 5 vs 19 of 667 (28%) in the UC group (absolute difference -9%, 90% credible interval -21.0-3.1). • On day 14, the proportion of patients with noninvasive ventilation (NIV), high flow oxygen, mechanical ventilation (MV) or death was lower in the tocilizumab group: 24% (95% CI 13%-35%) compared with 36% (95% CI 33%-58%) in the UC group. • No difference in mortality over 28 days was found between the two groups., Association between early treatment with tocilizumab and mortality among critically ill patients with COVID-19. Gupta et al. JAMA Internal Medicine, • Patients treated within 2 days of ICU admission with tocilizumab (n = 433) had a lower risk of death compared with those not treated with tocilizumab (n = 3, 491) (hazard ratio [HR] 0.71, 95% CI 0.56-0.92) (Figure). o 125 (28.9%) of patients treated with tocilizumab and 1, 419 (40.6%) of patients not treated with tocilizumab died. o The estimated 30-day mortality was 27.5% (95% CI 21.2%-33.8%) in the tocilizumab-treated patients and 37.1% (95% CI 35.5%-38.7%) in the non-tocilizumab-treated patients (risk difference, 9.6%, 95% CI 3.1%-16.0%). • Compared to patients who did not receive tocilizumab, tocilizumab-treated patients: o Were younger (median age, 58 vs 63 years). o Had fewer comorbidities (hypertension, 54.0% vs 62.6%, coronary artery disease, 9.0% vs 14.4%, or congestive heart failure, 5.3% vs 11.1%). o Were more likely to have severe hypoxemia (47.3% vs 37.9%). o Were more likely to receive corticosteroids on ICU admission (18.7% vs 12.6%)., Efficacy of tocilizumab in patients hospitalized with COVID-19. Stone et al. NEJM, • Compared to placebo, early administration of tocilizumab in hospitalized COVID-19 patients did not (Figure): o Prevent progression to intubation or death (hazard ratio [HR] 0.83, 95% CI 0.38-1.81, p = 0.64). o Prevent clinical worsening (HR 1.11, 95% CI 0.59-2.10, p = 0.73). o Reduce duration of supplemental oxygen (HR 0.94, 95% CI 0.67-1.30, p = 0.69)., Effect of tocilizumab vs standard care on clinical worsening in patients hospitalized with COVID-19 pneumonia: A randomized clinical trial. Salvarani et al. JAMA Internal Medicine, • There was no difference in rates of clinical worsening (admission to ICU with mechanical ventilation, respiratory distress, or death) in patients who received tocilizumab, n = 17, 28.3%, compared with those who received standard care, n = 17; 27.0% (rate ratio = 1.05, 95% CI 0.59-1.86, p = 0.87) (Figure 1). o Groups did not differ in time to clinical worsening. • Patients who received tocilizumab did not differ from control patients in ICU admission rate (10.0% vs 7.9%) or in rate of hospital discharge at 14 (56.7% vs 57.1%) or 30 days (90.0% vs 92.1%)., Herd immunity and implications for SARS-CoV-2 control. Omer et al. JAMA Insights, • Highly communicable pathogens have a large reproductive number (R0); therefore, a greater proportion of the population must be immune to decrease sustained transmission and achieve herd immunity (Figure). • Herd immunity threshold (~60% for SARS-CoV-2) in the US without vaccination would require 198 million infections (Figure). o With a 0.5% fatality rate, up to 1 million deaths could result. • Currently, it is estimated that <10% of the population has been infected based on antibody testing. o There is little precedent for achieving herd immunity without vaccination. o While a SARS-CoV-2 vaccine could help achieve herd immunity, effectiveness and potential coverage of a future vaccine are not yet known., Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in children aged 0 to 19 years in childcare facilities and schools after their reopening in May 2020, Baden-Württemberg, Germany. Ehrhardt et al. Eurosurveillance, • Child-to-child transmission in schools and childcare facilities was not common and was not the primary cause of SARS-CoV-2 infection in children. • 137 (30%) of 453 COVID-19 cases among children 0–9 years of age attended school or childcare settings for at least 1 day in their infectious period, 316 (70%) were at home during their entire infectious period. o 6/137 (4.4%) infected a total of 11 additional students, no secondary infections were detected for the remaining cases. o Four students were infected by two teachers. o All remaining cases (n = 437) were infected by sources outside of school and childcare facilities (Figure). • Infection prevention and control measures were not uniformly implemented in childcare facilities and schools., Modeling COVID-19 scenarios for the United States. IHME COVID-19 Forecasting Team, Nature Medicine, • Projected cumulative lives lost to COVID-19 between September 2020 and February 2021: o Reference scenario: 511, 373 lives lost (uncertainty Interval [UI] 496, 578–578, 347). o Mandate easing scenario: 1, 053, 206 lives lost (UI 759, 693–1, 452, 397). • Projected lives saved with non-pharmaceutical interventions: o Universal, 95%, mask wearing scenario and social distancing: 129, 574 lives saved (UI 85, 284─170, 867). o 85% mask wearing and social distancing: 95, 814 lives saved (UI 60, 731─133, 077)., Decline of humoral responses against SARS-CoV-2 spike in convalescent individuals. Beaudoin-Bussières et al. mBio, • Levels of spike protein receptor binding domain (RBD)-specific IgG, IgA, and IgM antibodies in convalescent plasma (CP) significantly decreased from baseline (median 6 weeks after onset of symptoms) to 1-month follow-up (p <0.0001) (Figure). o The proportion of individuals with detectable anti-RBD IgM and IgA decreased from baseline to 1 month by 13% and 25%, respectively. • 96.8% of CP had antibody that bound to both SARS-CoV-2 RBD forms at baseline and 1 month. o The levels of antibodies binding to both forms decreased from baseline to 1 month. • Neutralizing activity against both SARS-CoV-2 forms was detected in 71% of CP at baseline; the proportion decreased at 1 month to 41.9% (VSV-G) and 51.6% (D614G). o Level of neutralizing activity also decreased from baseline to 1 month (p <0.0001 for both forms)., Waning antibody responses in asymptomatic and symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection. Choe et al. Emerging Infectious Diseases, • Antibody titers correlated with disease severity. o The geometric mean titer was 105 among asymptomatic persons, 161 among patients with subtle pneumonia, and 891 among patients with apparent pneumonia. o The geometric mean titer of neutralizing antibodies declined from 219.4 at 2 months after infection to 143.7 at 5 months after infection. • 71% of asymptomatic patients had detectable antibodies at 2 months after infection which declined to 57% at 5 months after infection. • 100% of patients with pneumonia had detectable antibodies at 2 months after infection. o At 5 months, 83% of patients with subtle pneumonia and 100% of patients with apparent pneumonia had detectable antibodies., COVID-19, Science"
